poem:
Aisles of Plenty

In the land of rust-red earth, I've roamed,  
through aisles where tin and bag call home.  
Forty chips and seventeen ginger beers,  
in fermented fields, taste-testing seers.  
Aldi, both the crown and curse claimed.  
In cogs of commerce, flavors named,  
this dance of goods, whose notes all blend,  
to test the tongues that never end.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "What I’ve learned from taste testing 290 Australian supermarket products: ‘Aldi has the best and worst of everything’ For the past year, I’ve been eating my way through the supermarket aisles of Australia. I’ve had 17 different yoghurts, more than 40 varieties of potato chips, 17 different ginger beers and almost every can of baked bean you can get. All up, I’ve tasted more than 290 goods and spent more than 200 hours eating, discussing". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: What I’ve learned from taste testing 290 Australian supermarket products: ‘Aldi has the best and worst of everything’ For the past year, I’ve been eating my way through the supermarket aisles of Australia. All up, I’ve tasted more than 290 goods and spent more than 200 hours eating, discussing
